text:
Dsiclaimer: This is the first time I'm downloading Tomcat.

I downloaded Tomcat milestone build b3 from jakarata.apache.org around an hour 
back. After gzipping -d and untarring the build, I tried starting the server 
using bin/startup.sh. However it gave me the message

"You must set JAVA_HOME to point to your Java Development Kit installation".

I did an echo $JAVA_HOME immediately after this operation and JAVA_HOME does 
seem to point to a valid directory.

<EXECUTION-LOG>
/tmp/jakarta-tomcat-4.0-b3/bin 1965 $ startup.sh
Guessing CATALINA_HOME from catalina.sh to ./..
Setting CATALINA_HOME to ./..
You must set JAVA_HOME to point at your Java Development Kit installation
/tmp/jakarta-tomcat-4.0-b3/bin 1966 $ echo $JAVA_HOME
/usr/local/java/jdk1.3/solaris
/tmp/jakarta-tomcat-4.0-b3/bin 1967 $ ls /usr/local/java/jdk1.3/solaris
COPYRIGHT     README.sparc  demo          include       lib
LICENSE       bin           hotvm.tar     jre           src.jar
</EXECUTION-LOG>

It's not letting me start the catalina server this way. However alternatively if 
I set the JAVA_HOME in catalina.sh, then it does start the server.

Is it that I need to set the JAVA_HOME in catalina.sh ? If yes, then the 
appropriate message should be displayed.

Is there any other environment setting that should be done ? If yes, then that 
should be mentioned.

Regards,
-Arun
creator: arun.gupta@sun.com
craig.mcclanahan@sun.com
text:
Hmm, the actual test for this in the catalina.sh script is:

  if [ -z "$JAVA_HOME" ] ; then
    echo You must set JAVA_HOME ...
    exit 1
  fi

which should only complain if $JAVA_HOME is either not set, or is set to a 
zero-length string.  Are you sure that it is actually getting passed on to the 
/bin/sh on your server?  Could you try creating a shell script with only the 
above lines, and see if it behaves properly?
Works correctly for me on both Solaris (5.7) and Linux.
